item.description: [[C- A DSL allows for abstraction]]. [[C- End-user programming enables the developers to be lazy about their backlog of feature requests]].

item.title: C- A DSL could be a powerful interface for entering information into a discourse graph
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] [[C- A structural editor can make a DSL approachable to end-users]] [[C- A DSL would let people write in a certain syntax and notation that gets transformed by functions into a data structure that can be manipulated by pre-built or custom-built functions]]

item.title: C- A DSL speeds up the author
item.description: See this example here: doing some relatively common action in a GUI is never going to really get that much faster, whereas in programming, with abstractions and copy-paste, a DSL can get faster.

item.title: C- A key requirement to participating in a discourse graph for a specific domain is knowing the vocabulary used in that graph
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] Search queries only work when the searcher knows the vocabulary used in the information being searched.

item.title: C- A structural editor can make a DSL approachable to end-users
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] Text does not need to be people’s interface for editing code. Structural editors like Fructure can make it impossible to write code that doesn’t work.

item.title: C- A structural editor could allow people to make and edit data structures
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] In [[Notion]], you have many different views of the same underlying relational databases. You can edit or view them as Tables, Calendars, Boards, Lists, Galleries, and Gantt Charts.

item.title: C- An ideal decentralized discourse graph would enable people to view information at different levels of granularity through a ZUI
item.description: See the [[ZUI]] page for a definition. Imagine being able to jump in and see a birds eye view or get into the weeds.

item.title: C- An ideal decentralized knowledge graph would map a social graph and a knowledge graph
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] [[Q- Should social knowledge management be thought of as social networks with really solid defaults, conventions, and incentives]]

item.title: C- An increasing amount of structure leads to entropy
item.description: This claim is simple - as people create more structured systems, they create more work around maintenance. The more work is required to make sure any given piece of information is consistent with a larger system, the more likely the information is to fall outside of the system.

item.title: C- Breaking ideas down into component parts facilitates creative reinterpretation
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Joel Chan]] Breaking ideas down into their component parts allows us to creatively reinterpret ideas for new purposes, such as creating a new understanding of a problem, or creatively reuse ideas in new contexts.

item.title: C- Bulk refactors are a necessary primitive to maintaining a decentralized discourse graph
C- Composability facilitates synthesis
item.description: The basic intuition here is that because synthesis involves creating a whole from new parts, composability facilitates synthesis. As it is difficult to compose large chunks of highly nuanced information, [[C- Compression facilitates synthesis|compression]] facilitates composability by giving individuals smaller, easier to remember “handles” to piece together, through a mechanism more fully described in [[C- Hypertext enables communication with high information density]].

item.title: C- Compression and contextualizability are in tension
C- Compression facilitates synthesis
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Joel Chan]] Synthesis is creating a new whole out of component parts. But what should the “parts” look like?

item.title: C- Context is necessary for knowledge reuse
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Joel Chan]] There is a long history of research in computer-supported cooperative work (CSCW) that documents how knowledge needs to be contextualized to be usefully reused.

item.title: C- Curation is an important role in maintaining a decentralized discourse graph
C- Current tools do not support flexible exploration and refactoring of structures as they inevitably evolve
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] Predefining a system limits our ability to explore alternatives outside the current structure. This cascades into the decisions to be made while in the act of work – what folder to place the note in, what naming conventions to use, what metadata should be added, and on.

item.title: C- Designing for ambient review is a rich opportunity space
item.description: If [[People don’t intentionally review old notes]] but still want old notes to resurface, we might ask how to display that information in an ambient manner, in contrast to traditional approaches that require individuals to explicitly choose to review old notes.

item.title: C- Discourse graphs could significantly accelerate human synthesis work
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Joel Chan]] An exciting hypothesis that motivates this work is that making discourse graphs widely available could accelerate human synthesis work, and thereby [[C- Effective synthesis is necessary for innovation and scientific progress|accelerate innovation and scientific discovery]].

item.title: C- Effective individual synthesis systems (seem to mostly) exist (for a select few)
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Joel Chan]], [[P- Rob Haisfield]] References bricolage, using a slipbox, synthetic notes, framework of qualitative analysis to literature reviewing.

item.title: C- Effective synthesis is necessary for innovation and scientific progress
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Joel Chan]] The advanced understanding from an effective synthesis can be a powerful force multiplier for choosing effective studies and operationalizations,1 and may be especially necessary for problems where it is difficult or impossible to construct decisive experimental tests.

item.title: C- Emoji reactions are a form of social tagging
C- End user programming enables people to bulk process notes
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] Bulk processing is basically what computation was made for! We can see promising directions with [[Q- How might we apply map filter reduce to notes and what other primitives are relevant to this domain|map, filter, and reduce]].

item.title: C- End-user programming enables the developers to be lazy about their backlog of feature requests
item.description: This was a claim from [[P- Geoffrey Litt]] on his episode of the Metamuse Podcast.

item.title: C- End-user scripting enables creative workarounds
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] User skill level increases over time, and people with high User Involvement understand your app’s core mechanisms so well that, when they face a new problem, they are able to come up with creative workarounds by rubber-banding multiple actions together.

item.title: C- Highlighted and lowlighted search results map to how well results map to intentions
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] What if the choice architecture for interacting with search results allowed you to indicate the strength of the links and how well it maps to your intended outcome?

item.title: C- Hypertext enables communication with high information density
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] [[C- Compression facilitates synthesis]] and hypertext facilitates compression. Andy Matuschak’s working notes, like a wiki, use hypertext to communicate in an information dense way.

item.title: C- Incremental formalization can mitigate risks of formalism in interactive systems
item.description: #[[🌲 zettels]] Tags: #[[D/Synthesis Infrastructure]] #[[incremental formalization]] #compositionality Description: The basic intuition is described well by [[R- Formality Considered Harmful|@shipmanFormalityConsideredHarmful1999]]: user enter information in a mostly informal fashion, and then formalize only later in the task when appropriate formalisms become clear and also (more) immediately useful.

item.title: C- Incrementally processing notes is a key user behavior to promote synthesis
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]], [[P- Brendan Langen]] This claim is a response to [[Q- What workflows and behaviors facilitate synthesis]].

item.title: C- It is difficult to predict whether structure now will be worthwhile later

[[C- People are lazy]], so if we can really leverage tacit annotation by enriching the choice architecture with options that add value, then we can perhaps fill in metadata and generate discourse.

item.title: C- Linked references are a smart default for related items
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Rob Haisfield]] Assuming you’re not using aliases, a plain text search in [[Obsidian]] for [[page]] within quotations is functionally indistinguishable from the backlinks for that page.

item.title: C- Making editors identifiable incentivizes high quality reviews
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Brendan Langen]] In [[R- Science as Pull Requests]], [[P- Cortex Futura]] paints a picture of an open source, engineering-focused academic review process of the future.

item.title: C- Many products are simply specialized interfaces on top of Excel
item.description: Authored By:: The Unbundling of Excel. Hundreds of B2B startups have been built by taking a job currently being done in Excel and trying to accomplish the job in more optimized, purpose-built B2B software.

item.title: C- Most people will primarily consume information
item.description: Authored By:: [[P- Brendan Langen]], [[P- Rob Haisfield]] Statistics over the years cite a 90-9-1 rule to contributors in online communities, and although that does not hold up across all communities, the majority of people fall into the consumption-only group (90%).

item.title: C- Most scholarly communication infrastructure operates on the document as the base unit
item.description: Even though we know that [[C- Scholarly argumentation operates on atomic statements and concepts as fundamental units]], our scholarly communication infrastructure doesn’t make it easy for scholars to find and work with these units: far from it!
